title: How Are New Products and Services Developed in Businesses?
summary: This article discusses the differences between developing new products for existing customers versus new markets. Developing new products for new markets is riskier because it requires establishing the company's credentials in addition to launching a new product. Existing customers are already familiar with the company and its products, making it easier to build on the relationship when launching a new product.
greenwashing: The article does not mention greenwashing, so it is impossible to determine whether the product or process innovation is an example of greenwashing.

title: Consumer Products
summary: George Washington Carver was a scientist and inventor who developed new uses for Southern agricultural crops and taught poor Southern farmers methods of soil improvement. He is best known for his work with peanuts, but he also developed uses for soybeans, sweet potatoes, and other crops. Carver's work helped to improve the lives of farmers and to promote sustainable agriculture.
green_innovation: TRUE, Carver's work on developing new uses for Southern agricultural crops and teaching poor Southern farmers methods of soil improvement can be considered a green innovation because it contributed to environmental sustainability goals, such as reducing resource consumption.
business_innovation: TRUE, Carver's work on developing new uses for Southern agricultural crops and teaching poor Southern farmers methods of soil improvement can be considered a business innovation because it was a new or improved business process that differed significantly from the firm's previous business processes and that has been brought into use in the firm.
green_product: TRUE, Carver's work on developing new uses for Southern agricultural crops can be considered a green product because it involved the use of environmentally benign materials, sustainable production processes that minimize energy consumption and waste, and product functionalities that support recycling and low environmental impact during usage and disposal.
green_process: FALSE, The article does not describe a specific process that meets the criteria to be a green process.
product_or_process: New uses for Southern agricultural crops and teaching poor Southern farmers methods of soil improvement

title: New Product Development and Introduction
summary: This article discusses the importance of testing new business innovations with customers and conducting internal reviews to ensure that the innovation meets business objectives. If the testing or review process identifies problems, the advice is to either make changes to the innovation or halt the project.

title: The best new products this month from Sonos, Fujifilm and more
summary: This article highlights new product launches from various brands, including Sonos, JBL, Fujifilm, Keychron, Hyperice, Marlow, and Petlibro. These launches span different categories, from headphones and speakers to cameras, keyboards, fitness and travel accessories, and pet supplies.

title: The Pioneer Woman’s 3 new Walmart-exclusive kitchen appliances are under $60 and available to shop now
summary: The Pioneer Woman has launched three new small kitchen appliances in a trendy Linen Speckle colorway: a 2-Slice Toaster ($30), a 6 Qt Programmable Slow Cooker ($35), and a 6 Qt Pressure Cooker ($59). The appliances feature a pattern that is "so fresh while also feeling nostalgic and traditional," and their neutral tone fits well into many different kitchens. The appliances are available exclusively at Walmart.

title: America's Most Innovative Companies
summary: IKEA plans to invest more than 4 billion euros ($4.4 billion) by 2030 to accelerate the transition to a circular economy and become climate positive by 2030. The company aims to reduce its climate footprint by 70%, with remaining emissions to be captured and stored or offset by 2030. IKEA plans to achieve these goals through a combination of measures, including using more renewable energy, improving energy efficiency, reducing waste and transitioning to more sustainable materials.
green_innovation: TRUE. IKEA's plan to invest in a circular economy and become climate positive by 2030 is a green innovation because it contributes to environmental sustainability goals, such as reducing greenhouse gas emissions and transitioning to a sustainable materials.
business_innovation: TRUE. IKEA's plan to invest in a circular economy and become climate positive by 2030 is a business innovation as it is a new or improved business process that differs significantly from the firm’s previous business processes.
green_product: TRUE. IKEA's plan to transition to more sustainable materials is an example of a green product as it aims to reduce negative environmental externalities.
green_process: TRUE. IKEA's plan to use more renewable energy, improve energy efficiency, and reduce waste are all examples of green processes that minimize environmental impacts and promote sustainability.

greenwashing: FALSE. IKEA's plan to invest in a circular economy and become climate positive by 2030 does not appear to be an example of greenwashing as the company has a long track record of sustainability initiatives and the plan is ambitious and comprehensive.

title: New iMac
summary: There are rumors of a new larger iMac with M-series processors and a redesigned display, but Apple has confirmed that it isn't working on a 27-inch model, and new product announcements may not be until 2025.  The new iMac could have a 30-inch or 32-inch display with ProMotion and mini-LED technology, and it could be powered by M3 Pro and M3 Max processors.  The iMac Pro is increasingly unlikely as the Mac Pro now runs M2 Ultra.
green_innovation: TRUE, the new iMac would be a green innovation because it would reduce energy consumption with its more efficient processor and decrease the use of harmful substances by using more environmentally friendly materials in its production.
business_innovation: TRUE, the new iMac would be a business innovation because it would be a new product that differs significantly from Apple's previous products and would be brought to market by Apple.
green_product: TRUE, the new iMac would be a green product because it would be designed, manufactured, and used in a way that significantly reduces its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: FALSE, the article does not describe a specific process that meets the criteria for a green process.
